items.title: Fewer EVs need fewer batteries: Ford and SK On end their joint venture
items.summary: Ford will keep the plant in Kentucky, SK gets the one in Tennessee.
items.body: Cast your mind back to 2021. Electric vehicles were hot stuff, buoyed by Teslaâ€™s increasingly stratospheric valuation and a general optimism fueled by what would turn out to be the most significant climate-focused spending package in US history. For some time, automakers had been promising an all-electric future, and they started laying the groundwork to make that happen, partnering with battery suppliers and the like. Take Fordâ€”that year, it announced a joint venture with SK to build a pair of battery factories, one in Kentucky, the other in Tennessee. BlueOvalSK represented an $11.4 billion investment that would create 11,000 jobs, we were told , and an annual output of 60 GWh from both plants. Four years later, things look very different. EV subsidies are dead, as is any inclination by the current government to hold automakers accountable for selling too many gas guzzlers. EV-heavy product plans have been thrown out, and designs for new combustion-powered cars are being dusted off and spiffed up. Fewer EVs means a need for fewer batteries, and today we saw that in evidence when it emerged that Ford and SK On are ending their battery factory joint venture. Read full article Commâ€¦

items.title: No sterile neutrinos after all, say MicroBooNE physicists
items.summary: There's a less than 5 percent chance that earlier anomalies can be explained by fourth neutrino "flavor."
items.body: Since the 1990s, physicists have pondered the tantalizing possibility of an exotic fourth type of neutrino, dubbed the â€œsterileâ€ neutrino, that doesnâ€™t interact with regular matter at all, apart from its fellow neutrinos, perhaps. But definitive experimental evidence for sterile neutrinos has remained elusive. Now it looks like the latest results from Fermilabâ€™s MiniBooNE experiment have ruled out the sterile neutrino entirely, according to a paper published in the journal Nature. How did the possibility of sterile neutrinos even become a thing? It all dates back to the so-called â€œsolar neutrino problem.â€ Physicists detected the first solar neutrinos from the Sun in 1966. The only problem was that there were far fewer solar neutrinos being detected than predicted by theory, a conundrum that became known as the solar neutrino problem. In 1962, physicists discovered a second type (â€œflavorâ€) of neutrino, the muon neutrino . This was followed by the discovery of a third flavor, the tau neutrino , in 2000. Physicists already suspected that neutrinos might be able to switch from one flavor to another. In 2002 , scientists at the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory (or SNO) announced that they â€¦

items.title: Disney invests $1 billion in OpenAI, licenses 200 characters for AI video app Sora
items.summary: Three-year deal lets users create AI videos of Mickey Mouse, Darth Vader, and more.
items.body: On Thursday, The Walt Disney Company announced a $1 billion investment in OpenAI and a three-year licensing agreement that will allow users of OpenAIâ€™s Sora video generator to create short clips featuring more than 200 Disney, Marvel, Pixar, and Star Wars characters. Itâ€™s the first major content licensing partnership between a Hollywood studio related to the most recent version of OpenAIâ€™s AI video platform, which drew criticism from some parts of the entertainment industry when it launched in late September. â€œTechnological innovation has continually shaped the evolution of entertainment, bringing with it new ways to create and share great stories with the world,â€ said Disney CEO Robert A. Iger in the announcement. â€œThe rapid advancement of artificial intelligence marks an important moment for our industry, and through this collaboration with OpenAI we will thoughtfully and responsibly extend the reach of our storytelling through generative AI, while respecting and protecting creators and their works.â€ The deal creates interesting bedfellows between a company that basically defined modern US copyright policy through congressional lobbying back in the 1990s and one that has argued â€¦

items.title: OpenAI signs deal to bring Disney characters to Sora and ChatGPT
items.summary: It looks like Disney wasted no time delivering on CEO Bob Igerâ€™s promise to bring AI-generated content to Disney+. On Thursday, the company announced the start of a three-year licensing agreement with OpenAI to bring more than 200 of its beloved characters, including those from Star Wars and Pixar,â€¦

items.title: Oracle shares slide on $15B increase in data center spending
items.summary: Company raises its capital expenditure forecast as it doubles down on AI infrastructure bet.
items.body: Oracle stock dropped after it reported disappointing revenues on Wednesday alongside a $15 billion increase in its planned spending on data centers this year to serve artificial intelligence groups. Shares in Larry Ellisonâ€™s database company fell 11 percent in pre-market trading on Thursday after it reported revenues of $16.1 billion in the last quarter, up 14 percent from the previous year, but below analystsâ€™ estimates. Oracle raised its forecast for capital expenditure this financial year by more than 40 percent to $50 billion. The outlay, largely directed to building data centers, climbed to $12 billion in the quarter, above expectations of $8.4 billion. Read full article Comments

items.title: TIME names â€˜Architects of AIâ€™ its Person of the Year
items.summary: TIME Magazine has named the 'Architects of AI' its Person of the Year, who include Jensen Huang, Elon Musk, Sam Altman, Mark Zuckerberg, Lisa Su, Dario Amodei, Demis Hassabis, and Fei-Fei Li

items.title: NASA just lost contact with a Mars orbiter, and will soon lose another one
items.summary: If NASA is serious about exploring Mars, it's past time to send new missions.
items.body: NASA has lost contact with one of its three spacecraft orbiting Mars, the agency announced Tuesday. Meanwhile, a second Mars orbiter is perilously close to running out of fuel, and the third mission is running well past its warranty. Ground teams last heard from the Mars Atmosphere and Volatile Evolution, or MAVEN, spacecraft on Saturday, December 6. â€œTelemetry from MAVEN had showed all subsystems working normally before it orbited behind the red planet,â€ NASA said in a short statement . â€œAfter the spacecraft emerged from behind Mars, NASAâ€™s Deep Space Network did not observe a signal.â€ NASA said mission controllers are â€œinvestigating the anomaly to address the situation. More information will be shared once it becomes available.â€ Read full article Comments

The CPB is set to shut down after Congress approved President Trumpâ€™s request to rescind its funding . The Center for American Rights said the CPB shutdown should be used as an opportunity to reassign spectrum used by NPR and PBS stations to other entities. Read full article Comments

items.title: A new open-weights AI coding model is closing in on proprietary options
items.summary: Devstral 2 model scores 72% on industry benchmark, nearing proprietary rivals.
items.body: On Tuesday, French AI startup Mistral AI released Devstral 2, a 123 billion parameter open-weights coding model designed to work as part of an autonomous software engineering agent. The model achieves a 72.2 percent score on SWE-bench Verified , a benchmark that attempts to test whether AI systems can solve real GitHub issues, putting it among the top-performing open-weights models. Perhaps more notably, Mistral didnâ€™t just release an AI model, it released a new development app called Mistral Vibe. Itâ€™s a command line interface (CLI) similar to Claude Code , OpenAI Codex , and Gemini CLI that lets developers interact with the Devstral models directly in their terminal. The tool can scan file structures and Git status to maintain context across an entire project, make changes across multiple files, and execute shell commands autonomously. Mistral released the CLI under the Apache 2.0 license. Itâ€™s always wise to take AI benchmarks with a large grain of salt, but weâ€™ve heard from employees of the big AI companies that they pay very close attention to how well models do on SWE-bench Verified, which presents AI models with 500 real software engineering problems pulled from GitHub issuâ€¦

items.body: Amazon has been updating the large-screened Kindle Scribe tablet more frequently and regularly than it updates its standard e-readers, and today the company is announcing the tabletâ€™s third hardware update in four years. The regular Scribe is also being joined by a lower-end Scribe with less storage and no front light and an upgraded Kindle Scribe Colorsoft model with a color e-ink screen. This makes it only the second Kindle to include a color screen, after last yearâ€™s Kindle Colorsoft . Both the regular Kindle Scribe and the Kindle Scribe Colorsoft are available to order starting today for $500 and $630, respectively. Both of those devices include a Premium Pen accessory and 32GB of internal storage; 64GB of storage is available for an extra $50 for both devices. The cheaper front light-less Scribe is coming sometime next year and will run $430 for a model with a more modest 16GB of storage. (These are all much more expensive than the original Scribeâ€™s $340 launch price, but inflation, tariffs, and shortages are wreaking havoc with all kinds of tech prices for the past few years.) The Scribe and Scribe Colorsoft both come with an updated front light â€œwith miniaturized LEDs that â€¦

items.title: US taking 25% cut of Nvidia chip sales â€œmakes no sense,â€ experts say
items.summary: Trumpâ€™s odd Nvidia reversal may open the door for China to demand Blackwell access.
items.body: Donald Trumpâ€™s decision to allow Nvidia to export an advanced artificial intelligence chip, the H200, to China may give China exactly what it needs to win the AI race, experts and lawmakers have warned. The H200 is about 10 times less powerful than Nvidiaâ€™s Blackwell chip, which is the tech giantâ€™s currently most advanced chip that cannot be exported to China. But the H200 is six times more powerful than the H20, the most advanced chip available in China today. Meanwhile Chinaâ€™s leading AI chip maker, Huawei, is estimated to be about two years behind Nvidiaâ€™s technology. By approving the sales, Trump may unwittingly be helping Chinese chip makers â€œcatch upâ€ to Nvidia, Jake Sullivan told The New York Times . Sullivan, a former Biden-era national security advisor who helped design AI chip export curbs on China, told the NYT that Trumpâ€™s move was â€œnutsâ€ because â€œChinaâ€™s main problemâ€ in the AI race â€œis they donâ€™t have enough advanced computing capability.â€ Read full article Comments

items.body: Although many of us associate it with rally-derived machinery from the late 1990s and early 2000s, these days, Subaru has mostly abandoned its performance cars to concentrate on its true callingâ€”rugged, all-wheel-drive vehicles that are high on practicality, powered by horizontally opposed â€œboxerâ€ engines. One area where the brand has never particularly excelled has been fuel efficiency, which is where todayâ€™s test car, the Subaru Forester Hybrid, comes in. The last time Ars reviewed a Subaru Forester, it left us impressed. How about one with 40 percent better economy, in that case? Now, the 2.5 L flat-four engine operates on the Atkinson/Miller cycle, which generates 162 hp (121 kW) and 154 lb-ft (208 Nm). Thereâ€™s an electric motor-generator starter and an electric traction motor with 118 hp (88 kW) and 199 lb-ft (270 Nm) that work together to send a combined 194 hp (145 kW) to all four wheels via a symmetrical all-wheel drive system and a planetary continuously variable transmission. The Forester Hybrid is 183.3 inches (4,656 mm) long, 70.2 inches (1,783 mm) wide, and 68.1 inches (1,729 mm) tall, with a 105.1-inch (2,670 mm) wheelbase. items.title: Sperm donor with rare cancer mutation fathered nearly 200 children in Europe
items.summary: Children with the mutation have up to a 90% chance of developing cancer by age 60.
items.body: A single sperm donor who carries a rare cancer-causing genetic mutation has fathered at least 197 children across 14 countries in Europe, according to a collaborative investigation by 14 European news groups . According to their investigative report, some of the children have already died, and many others are expected to develop deadly cancers. The manâ€”Donor 7069, alias â€œKjeldâ€â€”carries a rare mutation in the TP53 gene, which codes for a critical tumor suppressor called protein 53 or p53. This protein (which is a transcription factor) keeps cells from dividing uncontrollably, can activate DNA repair processes amid damage, and can trigger cell death when a cell is beyond repair. Many cancers are linked to mutations in p53. Read full article Comments

items.summary: Appleâ€™s Studio Display hasnâ€™t been updated since it launched in 2022, but it remains one of the best monitors for the Mac-oriented, and right now you can pick one up for $230 off. This deal applies specifically to the tilt-adjustable model, which means you canâ€™t adjust the height of the built-in stâ€¦

items.title: Impeachment articles filed against RFK Jr., claiming abuse of power
items.summary: He's the "biggest self-created threat to our health and safety," Stevens said.
items.body: Rep. Haley Stevens (D-Mich.) filed articles of impeachment against Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Wednesday, accusing him of abusing the powers of his office and undermining public health, putting Americansâ€™ lives at risk. He â€œhas got to go,â€ Stevens said in a video announcing the impeachment articles. In an accompanying press statement , she said Kennedy, who rose to prominence as an ardent anti-vaccine activist, â€œhas turned his back on science, on public health, and on the American peopleâ€”spreading conspiracies and lies, driving up costs, and putting lives at risk.â€ She called him the â€œbiggest self-created threat to our health and safety.â€ It is very unlikely that an impeachment push will gain traction in the Republican-controlled Congress. No other Democratic lawmakers are backing the articles. Read full article Comments

items.title: MasterClass subscriptions are 40 percent off for the holiday season
items.summary: If learning a new skill is one of your New Year's resolutions, then you might want to know that MasterClass subscriptions are currently 40 percent off. This brings the top-tier subscription with offline mode and use on up to six devices down from $240 annually to $144. The entry-level plan, which sâ€¦

items.title: iOS 26â€™s new Messages feature got better when I changed this one setting
items.summary: Appleâ€™s Messages app scored a bunch of new features in iOS 26, including a new â€˜Screen Unknown Sendersâ€™ option meant to eliminate spam texts. My initial experience with the feature wasnâ€™t great, but tweaking one key setting has changed that. moreâ€¦

items.title: The new Homey Pro gets faster and smarter for Matter homes with no price increase
items.summary: Today, Homey has announced the new Homey Pro 2026, and the big update is straightforward: more RAM at the same price point. If you are not already familiar with Homey Pro, it is one of the most interesting home hubs on the market. It supports Matter, Thread, Zigbee, Z Wave, Wi-Fi, and even IR devicâ€¦

items.title: Dr. Oz tells his federal employees to eat less during the holidays
items.summary: â€œYou donâ€™t have to try every cookie on the holiday table,â€ wrote Mehmet Oz in an email to staff.
items.body: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the administrator for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and former daytime talk show star , has recently been emailing all federal workers in his agency weekly tips on â€œCrushing Cubicle Cravingsâ€ and how to avoid snacking in the office. â€œWe all love a fun cookie swap and potluck this time of year. With several teams across CMS hosting holiday gatherings this month, I am sharing some strategies to help you make healthier choicesâ€”while still indulging in festive treats,â€ Oz wrote in his latest missive, which appears as a recurring section in his weekly bulletin titled â€œFrom the Administratorâ€™s Desk,â€ according to emails viewed by WIRED. â€œSet your intentions,â€ writes Oz. â€œDecide in advance how many treats youâ€™ll allow yourself to enjoy and try to stick to that number. You donâ€™t have to try every cookie on the cookie table.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Projectors won us over in 2025
items.summary: Not long ago, you may have thought of projectors as complicated, unreliable or just too expensive. In 2025, though, consumer sentiment started to flip. Companies like Anker and Valerion made the projector experience more practical and immersive, helping drive consumer interest and, ultimately, saleâ€¦

items.title: Here are iPhoneâ€™s most downloaded apps and games of 2025

This year, the most downloaded free iPhone app was ChatGPT, while the top paid iPhone app was HotSchedules. Meanwhile, the top free iPhone game â€¦

items.title: Instagram now lets you take control of your feed (somewhat)
items.summary: A commonly expressed frustration with algorithmically-driven apps like Instagram is that users have no control over their feeds. They are instead shown what the app thinks they want to see, which is often wildly inaccurate. Meta is promising to provide at least a partial solution to the problem witâ€¦

items.title: AMDâ€™s next-gen â€œFSR Redstoneâ€ brings big gains, as long as youâ€™re using a new GPU
items.summary: "Redstone" is a promising mix of old and new ideas, but Nvidia is years ahead.
items.body: Nvidia, AMD, and Intel have all made high-quality image upscaling a cornerstone feature of their new GPUs this decade. Upscaling technologies like Nvidiaâ€™s Deep Learning Super Sampling (DLSS), AMDâ€™s FidelityFX Super Resolution (FSR), and Intelâ€™s Xe Super Sampling (XeSS) are all ways to transform a lower-resolution source image into a higher-resolution image, delivering better-looking games without requiring as much graphics hardware as youâ€™d need to render the higher-resolution image natively. Later additions have focused on improving ray-tracing performance and â€œframe generationâ€ technologies that boost frame rates by creating new AI-generated frames to insert between natively rendered frames. Generally speaking, Nvidiaâ€™s DLSS technologies have provided better image quality than AMDâ€™s FSR, but they have only been available on newer Nvidia hardwareâ€”the GeForce RTX 20-series or newer for most features, with frame-generation features locked to the RTX 40- and 50-series. FSRâ€™s results donâ€™t look as good, but they have benefited from running on just about anything, including older GPUs, Nvidia GPUs, and even integrated Intel and AMD GPUs. Today, AMD is trying to shift that dynamic witâ€¦

items.title: Kindle Scribe Colorsoft review: A very particular set of skills, for a price
items.summary: In a world where notifications persistently compete for our attention, distraction-free ereaders and writing tablets have found an audience. Putting your phone, laptop or iPad aside and curling up with a Kindle or a reMarkable tablet have become an almost ironic way for the tech-savvy to disconnectâ€¦

items.title: Shellyâ€™s new Plug Gen4 is a powerful Matter smart plug for less than $20

They are easy to install, use, and are usually low-cost. Today, Shelly has released the new Shelly Plug Gen4. Big point up front: it works with Matâ€¦

items.title: Instagram will let you control which topics its algorithm recommends
items.summary: For the first time, Instagram will start letting you control the topics its algorithm recommends, much as you now can on TikTok. The new feature is starting with the Reels tab but will eventually come to Explore and other areas of the app. Like much of what Meta is doing right now (for better or woâ€¦

items.summary: Apple has been accused of breaking the law by failing to comply with US sanctions after the App Store was found to have contain dozens of apps from sanctioned companies. The same was true of Google, though at a smaller scale. The banned apps were identified by the Tech Transparency Project, which sâ€¦

Similarly, there are winners and lâ€¦

items.title: Adobe brings Photoshop, Acrobat and Adobe Express to ChatGPT
items.summary: Back in October, OpenAI announced apps like Spotify and Canva would be accessible in ChatGPT. At the time, the company said more software was on the way, and now one of the most popular professional applications is available through the chatbot. Starting today, you can access Photoshop, Acrobat andâ€¦

items.title: Adobe Photoshop, Express, and Acrobat now available for free on ChatGPT
items.summary: Starting today, features from three of Adobeâ€™s flagship products will be natively integrated into ChatGPT, for free. Hereâ€™s how it works. moreâ€¦

items.summary: Around 210,000 budget portable power banks sold exclusively by Amazon USA are being recalled after they were found to have caused 11 fires resulting in both injuries and property damage â€¦ moreâ€¦

items.title: Operation Bluebird wants to relaunch â€œTwitter,â€ says Musk abandoned the name and logo
items.summary: â€œAbandonmentâ€ offers rare chance to reclaim one of techâ€™s most recognized brands.
items.body: A Virginia startup calling itself â€œOperation Bluebirdâ€ announced this week that it has filed a formal petition with the US Patent and Trademark Office, asking the federal agency to cancel X Corporationâ€™s trademarks of the words â€œTwitterâ€ and â€œtweetâ€ since X has allegedly abandoned them. â€œThe TWITTER and TWEET brands have been eradicated from X Corp.â€™s products, services, and marketing, effectively abandoning the storied brand, with no intention to resume use of the mark,â€ the petition states. â€œThe TWITTER bird was grounded.â€ If successful, two leaders of the group tell Ars, Operation Bluebird would launch a social network under the name Twitter.new , possibly as early as late next year. (Twitter.new has created a working prototype and is already inviting users to reserve handles.) Read full article Comments

items.title: Australia's social media ban faces challenges and criticism on day one
items.summary: As Australian teenagers lose access to social media, observers say there are still many unknown questions about the ban, which came into force on 10 December

items.title: Win hardware, collectibles, and more in the 2025 Ars Technica Charity Drive
items.summary: Help yourself to prizes by helping us raise money for good causes.
items.body: Itâ€™s once again that special time of year when we give you a chance to do well by doing good. Thatâ€™s rightâ€”itâ€™s the 2025 edition of our annual Charity Drive! Every year since 2007 , weâ€™ve encouraged readers to give to Penny Arcadeâ€™s Childâ€™s Play charity , which provides toys and games to kids being treated in hospitals around the world. In recent years, weâ€™ve added the Electronic Frontier Foundation to our charity push, aiding in their efforts to defend Internet freedom. This year, as always, weâ€™re providing some extra incentive for those donations by offering donors a chance to win pieces of our big pile of vendor-provided swag. We canâ€™t keep it, and we donâ€™t want it clogging up our offices, so itâ€™s now yours to win. This yearâ€™s swag pile is full of high-value geek goodies. We have over a dozen prizes valued at nearly $5,000 total , including gaming hardware and collectibles, apparel, and more. In 2023, Ars readers raised nearly $40,000 for charity , contributing to a total haul of more than $542,000 since 2007. We want to raise even more this year, and we can do it if readers dig deep. Read full article Comments

items.title: Incredible close-up of spider silk wins science photo prize
items.summary: Duelling prairie chickens, a snake-mimicking moth and a once-a-year sunrise at the South Pole feature in the best images from the Royal Society Publishing Photography Competition 2025

items.title: Human challenge trials have never been more popular
items.summary: The ethics of clinical trials that deliberately infect people with a disease aren't clear-cut â€“ but there's a strong case for doing more of them

items.title: Why do I feel lonely even when I'm surrounded by a festive crowd?
items.summary: Feeling alienated in others' company, or "existential isolation", can happen to us all. David Robson digs into the psychological literature for a solution for one reader

items.title: The two standout science-fiction films of 2025
items.summary: From Mickey 17 and M3gan 2.0 to a musical about the end of the world, this was an eclectic year for science-fiction films. Film columnist Simon Ings shares his two breakout hits

items.title: The four best science documentaries of 2025
items.summary: From animal rivals to Jane Goodall's last thoughts, enjoy 2025's best science documentaries, says our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley

items.title: Stop treating your pet like a fur baby â€“ you're damaging its health
items.summary: Pet owners' increasing tendency to see their animals as children rather than dogs or cats can have dire consequences. Owners, and veterinarians, should be wary, warns Eddie Clutton

items.title: The six best science-fiction shows of 2025
items.summary: What were the year's top sci-fi shows? Andor and Severance are still up there, but our TV columnist Bethan Ackerley also has some unexpected tips to share

items.title: Dogs may make us more caring and sociable by changing our microbiome
items.summary: We know that pets influence our microbiome, but scientists have now found that having a dog seems to change this ecosystem in a way that could boost our well-being

items.title: How deliberately giving people illnesses is supercharging medicine
items.summary: The covid-19 pandemic opened the door to once-controversial human challenge trials. Now, volunteers are willingly catching norovirus and influenza to reveal how our immune systems really fight back

items.title: Planned satellite launches could ruin Hubble Space Telescope images
items.summary: More than half a million satellites are planned to launch by the end of the 2030s, and simulations suggest they will have a severe impact on space-based astronomy

items.title: Forming moon may have taken three big impacts early in Earthâ€™s history
items.summary: Conventionally, the moon is thought to have formed during one big impact, but a three-impact model might make more sense

items.title: Helldivers 2 on-disk size 85% reduction
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Ancient human artefacts found near caves in Arabian desert
items.summary: Today, the deserts of the Arabian peninsula are inhospitable â€“ but 100,000 years ago, the area was full of animals and ancient humans

items.title: Why quantum mechanics says the past isnâ€™t real
items.summary: The famous double-slit experiment brings into question the very nature of matter. Its cousin, the quantum eraser experiment, makes us question the very existence of time â€“ and how much we can manipulate it

items.title: Black hole entropy hints at a surprising truth about our universe
items.summary: Two clashing ideas about disorder inside black holes now point to the same strange conclusions, and it could reshape the foundations of how we think about space and time

items.title: Can viral relationship tests really tell you about your relationship?
items.summary: Is there any science to viral relationship tests like the bird test, the orange peel theory and the moon phase test? Emily Impett, a professor of psychological and brain sciences at the University of Toronto, has the answers

items.title: Asteroid Bennu carries all the ingredients for life as we know it
items.summary: We knew from prior analyses that a distant asteroid sampled in 2020 carried all but one of the molecules needed to kick-start life, and researchers have just found the missing ingredient: sugar

items.title: Coral reefs have fuelled severe global warming in Earth's past
items.summary: Over the past 250 million years, periods when coral reef growth has peaked have coincided with big rises in sea temperatures

items.title: We now have a greater understanding of how exercise slows cancer
items.summary: Tumour growth is reduced by exercise due to a shift in the bodyâ€™s metabolism that means muscle cells outcompete cancer cells in the race to get sugar to grow

items.title: A sinister, deadly brain protein could reveal the origins of all life
items.summary: We have long struggled to determine how the first living organisms on Earth came together. Now, surprising evidence hints that poorly understood prions may have been the vital missing ingredient

items.title: Man unexpectedly cured of HIV after stem cell transplant
items.summary: A handful of people with HIV have been cured after receiving HIV-resistant stem cells â€“ but a man who received non-resistant stem cells is also now HIV-free

items.title: Cats can overcome fear of water to benefit from aquatic therapy
items.summary: Vets have developed a training protocol to help cats benefit from water-based rehabilitation therapies, in spite of their natural aversion to water

items.title: The best new science fiction books of December 2025
items.summary: From a new collection of shorter fiction by Brandon Sanderson to Simon StÃ¥lenhagâ€™s new work, via a Stranger Things novel, Decemberâ€™s new sci-fi features some compelling and intriguing offerings

items.title: Was a little-known culture in Bronze Age Turkey a major power?
items.summary: Archaeologists have gathered evidence from hundreds of Bronze Age sites in western Turkey that could be remnants of a civilisation that has been largely overlooked

items.title: 'Raise hell' - the fastest bowler you might not have heard of
items.summary: The story of Duncan Spencer, the "frighteningly fast" bowler who could have played for England or Australia.

items.summary: Comments

items.title: Giant of the Attic: On the Majesty of Alan Moore
items.summary: Comments

items.title: Ancient humans took two routes to Australia 60,000 years ago
items.summary: Scientists have long tried to uncover the perilous journey humans took to reach the ancient land mass that now makes up Australia. Now, a genetic study has edged us closer to understanding how and when they achieved this

items.title: Why Googleâ€™s custom AI chips are shaking up the tech industry
items.summary: Google is reportedly in talks to sell its tensor processing units â€“ a type of computer chip specially designed for AI â€“ to other tech companies, a move that could unsettle the dominant chip-maker Nvidia

items.title: Upheavals to the oral microbiome in pregnancy may be behind tooth loss
items.summary: Dental problems often arise or get worse during pregnancy, and a new study hints that rapid changes to the oral microbiome at this time could be at least partly to blame

items.title: Africaâ€™s forests are now emitting more CO2 than they absorb
items.summary: Logging and mining are destroying swathes of the Congo rainforest, with the result that African forests went from being a carbon sink to a carbon source in 2010 to 2017

items.title: Plastic can be programmed to have a lifespan of days, months or years
items.summary: Inspired by natural polymers like DNA, chemists have devised a way to engineer plastic so it breaks down when it is no longer needed, rather than polluting the environment

items.title: Our verdict on sci-fi novel Every Version of You: We (mostly) loved it
items.summary: New Scientist Book Club members share their thoughts on our November read, Grace Chan's Every Version of You

items.title: Read an extract from The Player of Games by Iain M. Banks
items.summary: The New Scientist Book Club is currently reading Iain M. Banks's classic sci-fi novel The Player of Games. In this extract, we meet protagonist Gurgeh for the first time

items.title: Why sci-fi novelist Iain M. Banks was an â€˜astoundingâ€™ world-builder
items.summary: The New Scientist Book Club is currently reading the late Iain M. Banksâ€™s Culture novel The Player of Games. Fellow science fiction author Bethany Jacobs reveals how his work inspired her

items.title: Supermassive dark matter stars may be lurking in the early universe
items.summary: Stars powered by dark matter instead of nuclear fusion could solve several mysteries of the early universe, and we may have spotted the first hints that they are real

items.title: Origin story of domestic cats rewritten by genetic analysis
items.summary: Domestic cats originated in North Africa and spread to Europe in the past 2000 years, according to DNA evidence, while in China a different species of cat lived alongside people much earlier

items.title: Physicists have worked out a universal law for how objects shatter
items.summary: Whether it is a cube of sugar or a chunk of a mineral, a mathematical analysis can identify how many fragments of each size any brittle object will break into

items.title: Emergency response needed to prevent climate breakdown, warn experts
items.summary: Scientists sounded the alarm on the dire consequences of continued inaction at a briefing in London, warning that we could be heading for "unprecedented societal and ecological collapse"

items.title: Warming and droughts led to collapse of the Indus Valley Civilisation
items.summary: Hotter temperatures and a series of droughts in what is now Pakistan and India fragmented one of the worldâ€™s major early civilisations, providing a "warning shot" for today

items.title: Deadly fungus makes sick frogs jump far, possibly to find mates
items.summary: Chytrid fungus is a scourge to global amphibian populations, but before it kills some frogs, it can produce symptoms that may help the infected animals find mates and spread the fungus further

items.title: Monthly injection could replace daily steroid pills for severe asthma
items.summary: Daily steroid pills are often necessary for severe cases of asthma, but they raise the risk of several serious conditions. Now, scientists have shown that a monthly antibody injection can eliminate the need for the pills

items.title: Easter Island statues may have been built by small independent groups

items.title: Cold-water swimming has benefits for the brain as well as the body

items.title: 'Horrific and beautiful' whale rescue image wins photography prize
